comment: younger (toddler) brother_ also used as addressing term; also  eke
younger (toddler) sister, also used as addressing term, also used dʸɩdʸɩ
anay-atay is used in southern dialects and in the standard language,
Russian-based terms,  the accent is on the last syllable; also used  tʸatʸa, batʸu, papa
bubɩ is used mostly in middle dialects, it is not used when adressing
Russian loan, the accent is on the last syllable
variants of mother's mother; also čužay, čužayka, čuži, čužmumɩ
also addressing form of the younger brother to an elder brother in some dialects
baӡӡɩm is big or elder, pokcʸi (or picʸi) is small or young
Russian loan, sometimes also the Russian word is used, e.g. dvojurodnoj brat
Russian loan, sometimes also the Russian word is used, e.g. dvojurodnoj sestra

adressing from to elder brother's wife
wife's elder sister, Fin. Käly; also bultɩr
addressing term of the elder brother's wife toward the husband's younger brother
vɩlʸken lit. Is new+son's wife that means a newcoming wife
addresing form of elder brother's wifes to younger brother's wife

elder sister; in some dialects apa 'elder sister; aunt'
mumɩ-bubɩ is used mostly in middle dialects
also has meaning female animal e.g. mumi puni 'female dog', it is not used when adressing
a child in middle and northern dialects
relatives from mother's side have the first component čuž- which, I think, is relevent to Komi word čʸužnɩ 'to birth'
relatives from mother's side have the first component čuž- which, I think, is relevent to Komi word čʸužnɩ 'to birth'
the form like atay-zɩ means father-PX3PL lit. 'their father' , the 3PL became lexicalized here. The same thing happens with the husband's mother. Also , ayɩmurt, atayzɩ, dʸadʸayzɩ

also has meaning female animal e.g. mumi puni 'female dog', it is not used when adressing

relatives from mother's side have the first component čuž- which, I think, is relevent to Komi word čʸužnɩ 'to birth'
relatives from mother's side have the first component čuž- which, I think, is relevent to Komi word čʸužnɩ 'to birth'
also has meaning male animal e.g. ayi puni 'male dog'

here and further both components have the possessive suffix 3SG:  nɩl-ɩz-len pi-yez girl-3SG-GEN boy-3SG. Actually all kin terms in Udmurt are used with possessive suffixes. They are not used only when adressing, e.g. anay! "Mom!"  Except words nɩl-ɩ girl-1SG 'daughter!' and pi-ye boy-1SG 'Son!'
